Understanding the Modern Military
Student Story Reprise

Student Story Reprise

Now that you know more about the modern military, let's read Lieutenant Abrams' story.  We've included links to pop-ups with suggestions about how counseling services could have helped First Lieutenant Abrams discover the education and career path that was right for him. As you read the story and consider the new suggestions, consider similar situations with your students.

Brian C. Abrams
First Lieutenant
Quartermaster Officer
United States Army

  1. Schools and colleges

    I went to 4 different high schools and three different colleges;

    • Warren Township (Gurnee, IL)
      Freshmen Year of High School
    • Zion Benton (Zion, IL)
      Sophomore and Junior Years of High School
    • Jenkins (Savannah, Ga)
      Sophomore and Junior Years of High School
    • Lawrence Education Center (LEC) (Springfield, IL)
      Senior Extended
    • Savannah Technical College
      No degree
    • Wilbur Wright College (Chicago, IL)
      Associates in General Studies and Science
    • Chicago State University (Chicago, IL)
      Bachelors in Community/ Public Health

    I moved a lot, mostly having to do with my mother. Transfer Student As an out of state, transfer student with a history of attending multiple schools, would providing additional intervention/test preparation assistance been beneficial to the student at Jenkins High School? Were the advisors at the both LEC, and Savannah Technical College aware and supportive of Mr. Abrams’ goal of transferring to Savannah State University?   I’m not sure why we moved so much, but wherever she moved, I followed. I played basketball for all of the high schools I attended except for “Lawrence Education Center.” Lawrence Education Center is an alternative school and did not have any sports programs.

  2. High School

    High school was pretty fun for me. That’s when I began to learn who I was as a man. I did things early on to try to fit in, but it ended up not working out. I was a follower for a brief period of time before I learned that it was okay to be myself. If I could summarize high school for me, I’d say it wasn’t too bad. I didn’t like moving as much as I did, but I managed to get along with people everywhere I went. I just always remember feeling like I didn’t have a home. I didn’t go to high school in Chicago, and that’s where I’m from, but when my mom moved us (my older sister and younger brother) away, it was never quite the same. It’s also the reason why no matter where I moved, I was always home visiting family and friends.

  3. The Graduation Test

    My senior year was the most interesting year for me because we moved to a different state, Savannah, Ga. Savannah was totally different from Chicago. The size of the city, the food, and the weather, just to name a few. When we got settled and I started going to Jenkins high school, it was a culture shock. In addition to having a new complete setting, Georgia has what’s called a “Graduation Test.” You had to pass this in order to actually be eligible for graduation. I met some students that completed high school but couldn’t pass a portion of Georgia’s “Graduation Test”; therefore, they never received their diploma. Georgia’s “Graduation Test” is similar to an SAT or ACT, in which you get tested in English, Math, Social Studies, Reading, and Science. In each category, you have to meet the qualification of scoring a specific score, or else you fail that portion of the test and have to retake it at a later time. Long story short, I passed all of the tests except for Science and Social Studies.

  4. Test Retakes

    I continued to [take the tests] throughout [my senior] year leading up to graduation, but I continued to fail. I was getting discouraged because I could not pass those two tests to save my life. In Chicago, in order to graduate, you’d have to take the “Constitution Test” in order to be eligible for graduation. I was familiar with the school system in Chicago, IL, but not in [Georgia].

  5. Expecting

    While continuing to retake the parts of the test that I kept failing, I learned that I was expecting a child by the tail end of my senior year, and that’s when things changed for me. I didn’t show it, but I was embarrassed. I had friends, but I stayed to myself a lot. I never participated in the senior events Lack of Participation The student’s lack of participation in Senior events plus the recurring challenges with Social Studies and Science would have been a place to ask questions. If this had happened, perhaps multiple attempts would not have been required to pass the “Graduation Test” and Mr. Abrams would have been successful. leading up to graduation because I wasn’t sure if I was going to pass the graduation test (social studies and science). I was working at a Gas Station and had been working there since moving to Savannah. My focus changed because of the pregnancy. I still wanted to go to college, but I had to focus on passing the graduation test along with preparing to bring a child into the world. There was a lot on the line because if I didn’t pass the graduation test in time for graduation, I wouldn’t be able to start college on time like I had planned. College Plans College is often thought of as a goal in and of itself rather than a means to a larger goal. This might have been a good time to talk about not only requirements for attending college, but how finances and family would play into those plans. The military could be an option into financing college and providing a career trajectory upon graduation. A part-time service commitment might have been a good choice. Students who fail a graduation test but have otherwise completed all requirements for graduation can enlist in some branches of service, since not all states require a graduation or exit exam.

  6. Social Studies

    I ended up taking the graduation test for the last time a month before graduation. I passed Science and failed Social Studies. I did not graduate from Jenkins high school. I took one more shot at the graduation test after graduation and failed. I then made the decision to move with my uncle and aunt in Springfield, IL, to attend Lawrence Education Center. Once enrolled, I graduated three months after I started classes. I was the student of the month Having Success Along with the recognition of being “Student of the Month” this would have been a natural time to discuss future options and a revised timeline. The military is looking for bright students who can accomplish a mission. Having the student talk with a military recruiter as a subject matter expert might have been a great option at that point.  because of the time it took me to receive my diploma. The timeline I had planned out changed all because of me not passing the graduation test on time. There was nothing I could do but continue to move forward and plan what was next.

  7. Looking Back

    Looking back, when I was in high school, I wasn’t sure what I wanted to do early on. Since I played basketball, I knew I’d want a career surrounding sports. During my sophomore year, I researched various careers. Researching Careers This would have been an excellent time to talk about careers relating to health, sports, and fitness in both the civilian and military worlds. For example, you can work as a physical therapist in the Air Force, Army, and Navy.  The one that stood out to me was “Physical Therapy.” I was intrigued by the movement of the body. While I was working at the gas station during my senior year of high school, I had a lot of customers that would say the most random things to me. One customer told me, “You’re going to go on and do great things in life,” and another customer mentioned the “Air Force.” I often wondered what people saw in me that made them say such things.

  8. Overcoming Obstacles

    The customer that mentioned the “Air Force” didn’t really have an impact on me. I thought about the military for a brief moment after he mentioned it, but I didn’t pay it any mind. After having my son, things for me didn’t go well. I worked two jobs, ‘cashier at a gas station’ and ‘night auditor at the Marriott Hotel.’ I was also attending Savannah Technical College Attending College It would have been great to have a counselor at Savannah Technical College speak with him about his plans upon matriculation into their college, especially as it seems that he had plans to transfer to another state university. The military and the Department of Defense are the largest employers in the US. College career counselors, as well as financial aid advisors, should be aware of the military as a source of employment, education, scholarships, and loan repayment.  full-time, where I was going for my associates in Science in hopes to transfer to Savannah State University. Attending College If advisors at both the LEC and Savannah Technical College were aware of Mr. Abrams’ goal to transferring to Savannah State University they could have stepped in to reinforce academic major selection as well as Military options/service for ROTC and the parallel civilian careers/jobs. They could have also provided an overview of Military options and how they relate to the civilian job market.  Things did not go as planned; needless to say, I was faced with some very difficult obstacles. I ended up moving back to Chicago to better my life, and that’s when things changed for the better.

    When I moved back home, I enrolled at Wilbur Wright College. It was difficult for me to find a job, and boy, did I try. During that time, I knew I wanted something more out of life. I also wanted to make a decision that my son would benefit from. The military came to mind, and I took a leap of faith and joined (March of 2010). I took two semesters off because of basic and AIT training. Time Off During advisory sessions and depending on 1LT/Mr. Abrams' situation, was the Army Reserves option presented to 1LT/Mr. Abrams? 1LT Abrams could have attended college without taking two semesters off to attend Basic and AIT. The Army Reserves could have afforded 1LT/Mr. Abrams the options of remaining at home for family and continuing his education.  During the first couple of years of being in the military, I began to notice different options and career paths that I could take advantage of.

  9. Position of Power

    I knew I wanted to be in a position of power. I also knew that I wanted to graduate college with my bachelor’s degree. I came up with a plan to be able to do both. Once I graduated with two associates from Wilbur Wright (general studies and in science; 2014), I transferred to Chicago State University Transfer Student This is a great opportunity for both Mr. Abrams, his ROTC liaison and a college advisor and career counselor to come together and work on a plan with Mr. Abrams to be successful in his college and career plans with the Army. If he enrolled with the Army’s Concurrent Admission Program (CONAP), this would have been a very good time to review and discuss the transfer of credit from his AIT and other training and provided an opportunity for the admissions and career staff to learn more about military career and education opportunities.  where I enrolled into their ROTC Program and graduated in the fall of 2017. The rest is history. Not necessarily history because I have so much more I have to accomplish in life, but that’s where I was able to stay on track and not only graduate but also commission as an Officer in the Army.

    I believe the Army was the right choice for me. I didn’t grow up wanting to be in the military, let alone an Officer in the Army, but I must say, I’m satisfied. My job is challenging, to say the least, but overall, I’m happy that I can provide for my family and myself.
